C++ - Namespace

Created:2018-02-12  Last modified:2019-12-04

  • C++ File Structure
  • Namespace
  • References

  1. C++ File Structure

    C++ does not have strict rules for organizing source files. The source files can be typically divided into two categories, declaration files (.h) and implementation files (.cpp) Different from Java that puts declaration and implementation together and the file name must be the public class's name, the class name, .h file name and .cpp file name can be totally different. Moreover, one definition file can contain more than one class's definitions and one class can be implemented by several source files. (One source file can even just have one function implemented). Also, one .cpp file can implement several .h files.

    The .cpp files is binded to .h files by #include directive. The implementation function is connected to function declaration by Class:: symbol.

    The .h file also can contain the implementation. This is actually a feature of inline function. This implementation is treated as inline function and the inline keyword is added by default when ignored.

    The .cpp file can contain class declaration: but treat an a private class. and must be implemented in the same file.

    Term

    • driver file: The .cpp file contains the main function, which is the entry point for this program.
    • definition (implmentation):
    • declaration:

  2. Namespace

    Namespace keeps program name clean. Program can define functions that have the same name but in different namespace.

    Define/specify namespace

    namespace name{// this scope is under the a namespace}

    Specify namespace

    using namespace name; // the file is under the namespace

    A file can have multiple namespaces, a namespace can be mentioned in a couple of files

    The header file's class declaration and source file's class implementation must in the same namespace.

    The main function cannot be placed in any namespace.

    1. Example

              // .h file
        namespace H {
        
        class F{
         public:
          void print();
        };
        
        }  // namespace H
        namespace K {
        
        class F{
         public:
          void print(){
            std::cout << "K-F" << std::endl;
          }
        };
        
        }  // namespace K
      
            // .cc file
      namespace H {
      
      void F::print(){
          std::cout << "H-F" << std::endl;
      }
      
      }  // namespace H
      
      int main(){
        H::F f;
        K::F e;
        f.print();
        e.print();
      }

  3. References

    1. inline function (cplusplus.com)
